docs.snippet: Starting July 1, San Francisco will ban smoking in parks and open spaces, giving this city the distinction of having the most comprehensive and rigid no-smoking law in the nation.    Although an outdoor ban is not unique in California -- Los Angel...
docs.lead_paragraph: Starting July 1, San Francisco will ban smoking in parks and open spaces, giving this city the distinction of having the most comprehensive and rigid no-smoking law in the nation. Although an outdoor ban is not unique in California -- Los Angeles, Santa Cruz, Pasadena and eight other cities already limit smoking in playgrounds and on certain public beaches -- San Francisco will become the first city and county in the nation with a ban on smoking cigarettes and cigars in town squares, public gardens and city-owned playing fields, as well as in parks and along beaches.
docs.abstract: San Francisco bans smoking in parks and open spaces, first US city and county to do so; photo (M)

headline.main: San Francisco Bans Smoking in Parks And Other Open Spaces

docs.snippet: The specialists will be sent to Syria over the next eight months to carry out the extremely hazardous task of destroying its chemical weapons arsenal, the United Nations secretary general said Monday....
docs.lead_paragraph: The specialists will be sent to Syria over the next eight months to carry out the extremely hazardous task of destroying its chemical weapons arsenal, the United Nations secretary general said Monday.
docs.abstract: United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon says 100 specialists drawn from the UN and the organization that polices the global ban on chemical weapons will be sent to Syria over the next eight months to help dismantle and destroy its roughly 1,000-ton arsenal, extremely hazardous task that has never been tried and that could fail without Syria's cooperation.

headline.main: 100 Specialists to Carry Out Tricky Syria Disarmament
headline.print_headline: 100 Specialists to Carry Out Tricky Syria Disarmament

docs.snippet: When the Irish Government instituted a national ban on smoking in workplaces last spring -- including bars and restaurants -- the hospitality industry claimed that the measure would mean the death of that timeless tourist attraction, the tradition...
docs.lead_paragraph: When the Irish Government instituted a national ban on smoking in workplaces last spring -- including bars and restaurants -- the hospitality industry claimed that the measure would mean the death of that timeless tourist attraction, the traditional Irish pub. In fact, the Irish haven't stopped drinking or socializing; the smoking ban has simply changed how they go about it -- with much of the action moving outdoors, where smoking is still legal.
docs.abstract: Bars and restaurants in Dublin, Ireland, set up sidewalk cafes and other outdoor areas where patrons can smoke in wake of government-mandated ban on smoking in workplaces; photo (M)

headline.main: No Smoking Inside? That's No Problem for Dubliners.

docs.snippet: With Britain's ban on hunting with dogs due to take effect within weeks, openings for the final lawful events are filling fast. Indeed, some high-profile hunts favored by such notables as Prince Charles are fully booked.    But, according to the C...
docs.lead_paragraph: With Britain's ban on hunting with dogs due to take effect within weeks, openings for the final lawful events are filling fast. Indeed, some high-profile hunts favored by such notables as Prince Charles are fully booked. But, according to the Countryside Alliance, a pro-hunting lobbying group, there is still time for Americans and others to sign up for a last legal opportunity to crisscross the countryside in pursuit of a fox before the ban starts at midnight on Feb. 17.
docs.abstract: Openings for last of Britain's fox hunting events, banned beginning midnight February 17, are filling fast; ban affects only forms of hunting in which dogs kill foxes; photo (M)

headline.main: The Days Are Numbered for Britain's Dogged Pursuits

docs.snippet: Anyone looking for a tacky T-shirt on his next trip to Washington will have to shop some place other than the Mall.  The long strip of parkland between the Capitol and the Washington Monument was cleared of most T-shirt vendors on July 2 when a Fe...
docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone looking for a tacky T-shirt on his next trip to Washington will have to shop some place other than the Mall. The long strip of parkland between the Capitol and the Washington Monument was cleared of most T-shirt vendors on July 2 when a Federal judge ruled that the only items that may be sold there are printed materials -- books, pamphlets, bumper stickers and the like -- pertaining to a political cause.

docs.snippet: The Transportation Department says flying over Afghanistan is not safe, even for a Swiss plane, and Swissair, to its surprise, has just found out it will have to stop. Delta and Swissair have a code-sharing agreement on Swissair flights from Zuric...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Transportation Department says flying over Afghanistan is not safe, even for a Swiss plane, and Swissair, to its surprise, has just found out it will have to stop. Delta and Swissair have a code-sharing agreement on Swissair flights from Zurich. In February flights began to Delhi, and in April to Singapore and Bangkok, and they flew over Afghanistan. The Transportation Department has barred American-flag carriers from Afghanistan since May 1994; nine months later it extended the ban to code-share partners. Swissair has agreed to reroute the flights and pay a $50,000 fine, half to be refunded if there are no violations for a year. MATTHEW L. WALD
docs.abstract: Swissair, because of code-sharing agreement with Delta, is being barred from flying planes over Afghanistan; agrees to reroute flights and pay $50,000 fine, half to be refunded if there are no new violations for one year (S)
